clean_story:
The term diamagnetism originates from the Greek dia- meaning "through" or "apart"—and magnētis referring to "magnet"—coined in eighteen forty-five by physicist Michael Faraday to describe a weak repulsion in materials exposed to magnetic fields. Unlike ferromagnetism diamagnetic substances such as water copper or bismuth generate an induced magnetic field opposing the applied one. This phenomenon arises from Lenz’s law where orbital electrons adjust their motion to resist external magnetization.

Three related concepts are paramagnetism ferromagnetism and superconductivity.
